title: NIPS_2002_11_abs

sentences.text: Although the study of clustering is centered around an intuitively compelling goal , it has been very difficult to develop a unified framework for reasoning about it at a technical level , and profoundly diverse approaches to clustering abound in the research community .

Here we suggest a formal perspective on the difficulty in finding such a unification , in the form of an impossibility theorem : for a set of three simple properties , we show that there is no clustering function satisfying all three .

Relaxations of these properties expose some of the interesting -LRB- and unavoidable -RRB- trade-offs at work in well-studied clustering techniques such as single-linkage , sum-of-pairs , k-means , and k-median .

Entity-clustering_function_satisfying_al.label: clustering function satisfying all three
Entity-clustering_function_satisfying_al.description: An impossibility theorem stating that there exists no clustering function that satisfies all three simple properties.

Entity-an_impossibility_theorem.label: an impossibility theorem
Entity-an_impossibility_theorem.description: A mathematical statement showing that it is impossible to find a single clustering function that satisfies certain fundamental and seemingly reasonable properties.

Entity-there_is_no_clustering_function_s.label: there is no clustering function satisfying all three
aliases: there is no clustering function satisfying all three
Entity-there_is_no_clustering_function_s.description: The statement that it is impossible to find a single clustering function that satisfies all three specific and simple properties.

Entity-single-linkage.label: single-linkage

Entity-formal_perspective.label: formal perspective

summary: Although the study of clustering is centered around an intuitively compelling goal , it has been very difficult to develop a unified framework for reasoning about it at a technical level , and profoundly diverse approaches to clustering abound in the research community . Here we suggest a formal perspective on the difficulty in finding such a unification , in the form of an impossibility theorem : for a set of three simple properties , we show that there is no clustering function satisfying all three . Relaxations of these properties expose some of the interesting -LRB- and unavoidable -RRB- trade-offs at work in well-studied clustering techniques such as single-linkage , sum-of-pairs , k-means , and k-median .

Predicate-is_centered_around.label: is centered around
Predicate-is_centered_around.description: The predicate 'is centered around' indicates that the subject (study of clustering) has its primary focus or emphasis on the object (an intuitively compelling goal). It suggests a sense of orientation, direction, or concentration towards the specified objective.

Predicate-abounds_in_the_research_commun.label: abounds in the research community
Predicate-abounds_in_the_research_commun.description: The predicate 'abounds in the research community' indicates that a subject (e.g., an area of study or methodology) has a significant presence, prevalence, and influence within the academic field. It suggests that the subject is widely studied, discussed, and explored by researchers, resulting in a rich body of knowledge, diverse perspectives, and innovative approaches.

Predicate-shows_that.label: shows that
Predicate-shows_that.description: The predicate 'shows that' indicates a logical or empirical connection between the subject and object. It suggests that the information provided by the subject serves as evidence, proof, or demonstration for the truth of the statement described by the object.

Predicate-show.label: show
Predicate-show.description: To demonstrate or reveal something about a subject, often highlighting its properties, characteristics, or implications. The predicate 'show' indicates that the subject has some connection to the object, which may be an idea, concept, theorem, or other abstract entity.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is related to another more general or overarching concept (the object), which encompasses it as a specific instance.
